attributes.title: Stock Take
attributes.description:
A physical stock take was conducted on 14.03.2025 with the aim of establishing whether internal controls were effective and whether physical stock items were matching with those in the SAP system. 

         After stock take, it was noted that most stock items had nil variations with exception to;

  •         Bread stock had +23.75 pieces cumulatively

  •          Poly bags had a variance of +1,539 pieces cumulatively

  •          Utto 1.738 litres

         Details of the findings were as illustrated  in the table below;
attributes.recommendation: The branch management should maintain stock controls. Excess polybags in PFX41 variety should be looked into so as to ascertain the cause so that this is controlled
attributes.effect: Stocks were well controlled as depicted by minimal variances noted with exception to polybags which had an excess meaning there were lapses.
attributes.remediation_plan: Most stock items were well controlled with exception to polybags which need enhanced control to minimize variance noted

value: Stock is well controlled and we will maintain. We will follow up to check the cause of an excess in PFX 41 polybags variety
The stocks are well controlled and this has been due to shifts stock takes and handing overs. Polybags stocks will be closely monitored to ascertain excess of pfx 41.
In a prior audit report dated 25.02.25 bread had a +29.75 loaves, utto had -0.254 Litres, white flour had -4.045 kgs, and poly bags had -180 pcs
Current
Stock take is meant to check if physical count of items in the branch tally with with SAP system balances
Control to be enhanced to minimize variance noted in polybags
Operations/Production Department

attributes.title: Bread Return Analysis
attributes.description:
Analysis of all bread retuned to the branch from 1 March 2025 to 13 April 2025 was done to determine the reasons with corresponding sum of bread returned when converted to 400gms.

         From the analysis a total of 763 pieces of loaves worth Ksh 40,439 (using Minishop price) were returned. If those with torn wrapper and over supply were excluded it means that 386.5 (763-294.5-82) could be taken as damages hence a loss of revenue worth Ksh 20,484.50. Below is the illustration of the reasons for return and pieces of loaves in 400gms;
attributes.recommendation:
The reason of bread returns should be captured in the system when the branch manager is offloading vehicles from routes so as to capture accurately the reason for return. This is because the sale crew may give a reason which might be inaccurate. For instance reason of return being stated as over supply has far reaching implications where questions like how they loaded excess bread to the route or how orders were placed.

        The branch management should ensure bread produced is of good quality so as to reduce returns.
attributes.effect: The company is losing sales revenue when bread is returned to the branch due to reasons which can be controlled during production especially deformation, undersize or over/underbaked.
attributes.remediation_plan:
Production process should be checked to ensure bread produced is of the set standards so as to reduce returns related to production issue.

Supply as per order placed

value: We are trying to produce bread of good quality. Sometimes, the reasons given by sales crew may not be accurate. Therefore we request for these reasons to be captured when we are offloading the vehicles
All bread returns are captured in the system with the correct reasons as per the physicals. Manager must always confirm returns with the print out and make sure the reasons given are correct.
Current
This is the process of checking the magnititude of bread returns and reasons indicated for return.

Some of the reasons indicated like oversupply raises questions how while the branch supply more than what was requested by customers.  Control should be enhanced to ensure supply is done as per order and products produced meet the set standards so as to mitigate cases of returns
Operations/Production Department

attributes.title: Bread Weight Check
attributes.description:
Bread produced and packed in the branch were weighed randomly to determine if bread dispatched to the market was of the correct weight.

         From the sample selected on 13.04.2025 audit noted that all varieties weighed had underweight cases with exception to 400g CTW and 600g BT as illustrated in the table below;
attributes.recommendation: Spot checks should be enhanced to ensure all production parameters are followed so as to eliminate cases of underweight.
attributes.effect: Underweight bread dispatched to market exposes the company to risk of penalties if they are intercepted by the weight and measures officials.
attributes.remediation_plan: Spot checks should be enhanced to check if all set parameters are followed and machinery are working correctly so as to eliminate cases of underweights.

value: We will enhance spot checks from dividing to packing section to ensure all set rules are followed so as to reduce and eliminate cases of underweight.
Spot checks are done frequently and this has enabled improvement of branch efficiencies and weights.
In a prior audit report the follow were underweight cases; 400g CT - 3%, 400g Grande – 13%, 400g SN – 17%
Current
Packed bread are weighed randomly to check if they conform with set standard weight
A follow up should be done to check what is causing underweight cases in 800BT, 400g Long/Sandwich
Operations/Production Department

attributes.title: Bread Damages Check
attributes.description:
An analysis of production and market/supermarket damages was done to determine whether they were within the allowed percentage of 0.2% to total production and 0.5% of total sales respectively.

         A sample period of 44 days (1 March 2025 to 13 April 2025) was used to analyse bread damages. Audit noted that the percentage of average production damages stood at 0.22% of the total production while average market damages was 0.55% of total sales as illustrated in the table below;

         Audit noted that from 1st March 2025 to 13th April 2025 the SAP system had 1,367.5 pieces of loaves as market and supermarket returns but the manager’s book had 1,292.25 pieces hence a variance of 75.25 pieces worth Ksh 3,988.

Damages sent to Ingredients

        For the same period damages sent to ingredients was less by 26.83kgs or 67 pieces of loaves worth Ksh 3,551
attributes.recommendation:
The branch management should enhance control of production process so as to minimize cases of bread damages in the branch.

The branch manage should record all supermarket returns so that those booked in the system tally with his recordings.
attributes.effect:
Both production and market bread damages were above the set limits meaning the company was losing revenue through excess damages amounting to Ksh 2,544 (0.02*528/0.22)*53 and Ksh 6,225 (0.05*1,292/0.55)*53 respectively

         Variance in market and supermarket returns had variance implying lapses in follow up to ensure both records are matching.
attributes.remediation_plan: Control of production process and scheduled maintenance of ovens so to minimize cases of bread damages in the branch

value: We will try our level best to control bread damages in the branch by ensuring production procedures are followed. I will follow up to ensure all supermarket returns are recording in the bread damages book.

Damages are well maintained and more efforts will be enhanced to make sure are very minimal.

Supermarket damages are as a result of expiries and sales rep will be engaged to make sure they are well controlled.
In a prior audit report average production damages were averaging at 0.22% of the production and market damages stood at 0.46% of the total sales
Current
The test is aimed at determining whether the branch was operating below set maximum limits
From the findings, the company was losing revenues from excess bread damages
Operations/Production Department

attributes.title: Cash Count
attributes.description:
A spot check in the cash office was carried out with the aim of ensuring cash at hand was tallying with that of the cash flow balance.

         It was noted that the cashier fully accounted for the expected cash balance of Ksh 13,293 as at 14.03.25 after cashing in NSSF contributions from casual which were Ksh 3,827. After rechecking NSSF records, audit noted that there was a variance of Ksh 48. (3,875-3,827)
attributes.recommendation: The cashier should maintain the controls. The cashier should ensure all deductions from casuals match recordings on daily basis

value: Cash was well controlled.
Cashier to improve in recordings and maintain the controls.
In a prior audit report it was noted that expected cash had no material variance with the cash counted
Current
This is the process of physically counting cash held by the cashier to confirm if the amount is matching the balance brought forward
Cash was well controlled
Operations/Production Department

attributes.title: Debtor Analysis
attributes.description:
Outstanding debts were analysed as at 14 April 2025 to check the magnitude.

         It was observed that schools and other institutions had balances amounting to Ksh 452,568 as illustrated in the table below;
attributes.recommendation: Sales rep should be follow up with institution to ensure the outstanding amounts are paid when schools open.
attributes.effect: In cases where institutions have high debt it might imply that credit policy were not being followed
attributes.remediation_plan: Credit policy should be set for schools so as to reduce the amount they owe the company

value: Sales rep is following up with the institutions.
Sales rep is always on toes in following up customers and institutions debts.
In prior audit report the total outstanding debtors for institutions amounted to Ksh 641,271.50.
Current
Debtors analysis is tailed  towards checking the magnititude of outstanding balance owed by customers
From the analysis all debt was for school which need follow up especially doldol high school when they reopen.
Sales Department

attributes.title: Production Efficiency
attributes.description:
Production efficiency calculation from 1 March 2025 to 13th April 2025 was done to determine if the production workers hired were achieving the set production efficiency of 4.5 bags per worker.

         It was noted that the average production efficiency was 4.79 bags per production worker as illustrated in the table below;
attributes.recommendation: The branch management should maintain the allocation of production workers as per production target shift wise so as to ensure set efficiency is achieved.
attributes.effect: The branch achieved the set production efficiency target meaning that the cost of production was within budget.
attributes.remediation_plan: Production efficiency for the period was above set target of 4.5 bags per production worker

value: We allocate production workers as per target shift wise that why we meet the required efficiency
Branch efficiencies are well controlled and will be maintained.
From prior audit report average production efficiency was 4.70 bags per production worker
Current
This is the process of determining whether hired individual met the set target
Production efficiency at the branch was being attained
Operations/Production Department

attributes.title: Packing Efficiency
attributes.description:
Packing efficiency was calculated from 1 March 2025 to 13 April 2025 to determine if the packers hired were achieving the set packing efficiency of 97 crates per packer.

         It was noted that the average packing efficiency was 99.17 crates per packer as illustrated below;
attributes.recommendation: Hiring of Packers shift wise should be guided by the number of bags produced in the prior shift so as to maintain efficiency achieved for the period
attributes.effect: Average packing efficiency was above the set target and this implies that packing cost was within set budget
attributes.remediation_plan: Hiring of Packers (Wrappers) should be be done after taking into consideration loaves produced in prior shift so as to uphold achieved efficiency

value: We will try our best to maintain the achieved efficiency by hiring Packers as per loaves produced shift wise
To be maintained
From prior audit report average packing efficiency was 90.82 crates per Packer
Current
The test is aimed at checking whether wrappers hired achieve a target of 97 crater per wrapper in 8hours
Packing efficiency was well controlled
Operations/Production Department

attributes.title: Vehicle Mileage and Fuel Consumption Analysis
attributes.description:
Analysis of fuel consumption was done from 1 to 13 April 2025 to assess;

  •          Whether the standard fuel consumption set for each vehicle was being met

         It was noted that vehicles fuel consumption was well controlled during the period and Doldol route vehicle had saved 21.85litres for the sample period. An illustrated of the findings has been attached in the table below;
attributes.recommendation: Fuel controls in the branch should be upheld.
attributes.effect: Fuel was well controlled in the branch
attributes.remediation_plan: The control put in place should be maintained

value: Fuel is well controlled and we will try our best to maintain.
Fuel is always issued as per the kilometre covered as per the motor vehicle consumption thus making sure controls are correct.
The test is aimed at checking vehicles fuel consumption
Consumption per vehicle was well controlled
Transport/Fleet Department

attributes.title: Generator Fuel Consumption Analysis
attributes.description: The generator consumption rate was reviewed from 1 to 14 April 2025 so as to determine the consumption rate. Average consumption for the period was 12.59litres per hour. During the period 34 litres of fuel had been purchased and the generator had run for 2.7hours.
attributes.recommendation: The controls should be maintained by the management
attributes.remediation_plan: The control in usage of fuel should be maintained

value: Generator fuel consumption is well controlled as we only fuel after confirming the amount of fuel to buy
The generator fuelling is strictly done by the branch manager thus making sure controls are well maintained.
Current
This test is aimed at checking genset fuel consumption
Genset fuel consumption was well controlled
Transport/Fleet Department

attributes.title: Analysis of Branch Yield (Mixing Charts Analysis)
attributes.description:
Mixing charts and mixing chart summaries from 1 March 2025 to 13 April 2025 were examined to find out the branch’s utto consumption, average yield, cases of remix and summation of totals

        After examining the records the follow were noted;

  •        Average yield per bag was189.27per bag.

  •       Utto consumption was at 100%.

  •       Average production was 29.39 bags per day representing 54.42% of target which is 54 bags per day (Branch Capacity).

         The table below illustrates the findings;
attributes.recommendation:
On those days the branch run on full capacity, the branch management should ensure production target is achieved.

Promotion should be done within the existing routes so as to reach out to new customers hence  this will lead to improvement in production
attributes.effect: Target production in bags was not achieved meaning the branch’s capacity was under utilized
attributes.remediation_plan: Through promotion of company products, sales will increase hence increase in production

value: Production depends on sales hence we have to control our balance.
Branch capacity has always been underutilized due to low sales. Sales team are encouraged to open more depots to increase sales.
In a prior audit report, the branch average production per day was 20 bags which is 37% of the branch target of 54 bags, Average yield was 189.16 and there were no cases of remixes during the period
Current
This test is aimed at checking whether the  branch was able to achieve set yield, utto consumption rate and production target
Yield was achieved. However, production target was not achieved
Operations/Production Department
